sen.e: IKAGO no Ahe (the dates of birth and death are unknown) was a person of the Asuka era in Japan.

sen.j: 672年の壬申の乱で大海人皇子（天武天皇）側の高市皇子に従って都を脱し、後に大和国方面への増援軍の将の一人になった。
sen.e: At the Jinshin War, in 672, he followed Prince Takechi, who took the side of Prince Oama (Emperor Tenmu), made an escape from the capital and became one of the leaders of the reinforcement to the district of Yamato Province after that.

sen.j: 壬申の乱が勃発したとき、胆香瓦安倍は近江近江宮にいたらしい。
sen.e: When the Jinshin War broke out, it appeared that IKAGO no Ahe was in Omi palace.

sen.j: 大津にいた高市皇子は、父の大海人皇子の挙兵を知って京を脱出し、6月25日に鹿深を越えて積殖山口で大海人皇子の一行に合流した。
sen.e: Prince Takechi, who was in Otsu, knew about the raising of an army by his father, Prince Oama, and escaped from Kyoto, went through Kafuka on June 25 and merged with the group of Prince Oama in Tsumue yamaguchi.

sen.j: このとき高市皇子に従っていたのが、民大火、赤染徳足、大蔵広隅、坂上国麻呂、古市黒麻呂、竹田大徳と、胆香瓦臣安倍であった。
sen.e: At that time TAMI no Ohi, AKASOME no Tokotari, OKURA no Hirosumi, SAKANOUE no Kunimaro, FURUICHI no Kuromaro, TAKEDA no Daitoku and IKAGO no Shin Ahe were following Prince Takechi.

sen.j: 美濃国の不破郡に集結した軍勢は、7月2日に近江国と倭（大和）の二方面に分かれて進発した。
sen.e: The troops massing in Fuwa District, Mino Province set off in two groups separately toward Omi Province and Wa (Yamato) District on July 2.

sen.e: At that time, the individuals who led tens of thousands of troops to go directly to Omi were MURAKUNI no Oyori, HUMI no Nemaro, WANIBE no Kimite and IKAGO no Omi Ahe.
